drug.name: Cycloserine
drug.description: Antibiotic substance produced by Streptomyces garyphalus.
drug.synthesis-reference: Norman P. Jensen, "N-substituted cycloserine compounds, salts thereof, and processes for preparing them." U.S. Patent US3932439, issued December, 1956.
drug.indication: Used in combination with up to 5 other drugs as a treatment for Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) and is also used to treat tuberculosis (TB).
drug.pharmacodynamics: Cycloserine, a broad-spectrum antibiotic, may be bactericidal or bacteriostatic, depending on its concentration at the site of infection and the susceptibility of the organism. Cycloserine works by blocking the formation of these peptidoglycans. By doing this the walls of the bacteria become weak and it results in the death of the bacteria
drug.mechanism-of-action: Cycloserine is an analog of the amino acid D-alanine. It interferes with an early step in bacterial cell wall synthesis in the cytoplasm by competitive inhibition of two enzymes, L-alanine racemase, which forms D-alanine from L-alanine, and D-alanylalanine synthetase, which incorporates D-alanine into the pentapeptide necessary for peptidoglycan formation and bacterial cell wall synthesis.
drug.toxicity: Oral LD<sub>50</sub> in mouse is 5290 mg/kg, and in rat is over 5000 mg/kg. Symptoms of a cycloserine overdose include drowsiness, confusion, headache, dizziness, irritability, numbness and tingling, difficulty speaking, paralysis, abnormal behavior, seizures, and unconsciousness.
drug.absorption: Rapidly and almost completely absorbed (70 to 90%) from the gastrointestinal tract following oral administration.
drug.half-life: Half-life in patients with normal renal function is 10 hours, and is prolonged in patients with impaired renal function.

classification.description: This compound belongs to the class of organic compounds known as isoxazolines. These are compounds containing a five-member unsaturated aliphatic ring, with an oxygen atom adjacent to a nitrogen atoms, and three carbon atoms.

manufacturers.manufacturer: Purdue gmp center llc dba the chao center industrial pharmacy

drug-interaction.name: Ethionamide
drug-interaction.description: The risk or severity of adverse effects can be increased when Ethionamide is combined with Cycloserine.

drug-interaction.description: The risk or severity of adverse effects can be increased when Isoniazid is combined with Cycloserine.

drug-interaction.name: Picosulfuric acid
drug-interaction.description: The therapeutic efficacy of Picosulfuric acid can be decreased when used in combination with Cycloserine.

drug-interaction.description: Ethanol may increase the neurotoxic activities of Cycloserine.

Imming P, Sinning C, Meyer A: Drugs, their targets and the nature and number of drug targets. Nat Rev Drug Discov. 2006 Oct;5(10):821-34.

Noda M, Kawahara Y, Ichikawa A, Matoba Y, Matsuo H, Lee DG, Kumagai T, Sugiyama M: Self-protection mechanism in D-cycloserine-producing Streptomyces lavendulae. Gene cloning, characterization, and kinetics of its alanine racemase and D-alanyl-D-alanine ligase, which are target enzymes of D-cycloserine. J Biol Chem. 2004 Oct 29;279(44):46143-52. Epub 2004 Aug 9.

McCoy AJ, Maurelli AT: Characterization of Chlamydia MurC-Ddl, a fusion protein exhibiting D-alanyl-D-alanine ligase activity involved in peptidoglycan synthesis and D-cycloserine sensitivity. Mol Microbiol. 2005 Jul;57(1):41-52.
Chen X, Ji ZL, Chen YZ: TTD: Therapeutic Target Database. Nucleic Acids Res. 2002 Jan 1;30(1):412-5.
Overington JP, Al-Lazikani B, Hopkins AL: How many drug targets are there? Nat Rev Drug Discov. 2006 Dec;5(12):993-6.
Imming P, Sinning C, Meyer A: Drugs, their targets and the nature and number of drug targets. Nat Rev Drug Discov. 2006 Oct;5(10):821-34.

Feng Z, Barletta RG: Roles of Mycobacterium smegmatis D-alanine:D-alanine ligase and D-alanine racemase in the mechanisms of action of and resistance to the peptidoglycan inhibitor D-cycloserine. Antimicrob Agents Chemother. 2003 Jan;47(1):283-91.
Fenn TD, Stamper GF, Morollo AA, Ringe D: A side reaction of alanine racemase: transamination of cycloserine. Biochemistry. 2003 May 20;42(19):5775-83.
Fenn TD, Holyoak T, Stamper GF, Ringe D: Effect of a Y265F mutant on the transamination-based cycloserine inactivation of alanine racemase. Biochemistry. 2005 Apr 12;44(14):5317-27.

polypeptide.name: Alanine racemase
polypeptide.specific-function: Catalyzes the interconversion of L-alanine and D-alanine.

article.citation: DENGLER HJ, RAUCHS E, RUMMEL W: [On the inhibition of L-glutamic acid and L-DOPA decarboxylase by D-cycloserine and other isoxazolidones]. Naunyn Schmiedebergs Arch Exp Pathol Pharmakol. 1962;243:366-81.

polypeptide.name: Aromatic-L-amino-acid decarboxylase
polypeptide.specific-function: Catalyzes the decarboxylation of L-3,4-dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) to dopamine, L-5-hydroxytryptophan to serotonin and L-tryptophan to tryptamine.

go-classifier.description: cellular response to growth factor stimulus

article.citation: Kennedy DJ, Gatfield KM, Winpenny JP, Ganapathy V, Thwaites DT: Substrate specificity and functional characterisation of the H+/amino acid transporter rat PAT2 (Slc36a2). Br J Pharmacol. 2005 Jan;144(1):28-41.

polypeptide.name: Proton-coupled amino acid transporter 2
polypeptide.specific-function: Involved in a pH-dependent electrogenic neuronal transport and sequestration of small amino acids. Transports glycine and proline. Inhibited by sarcosine (By similarity).
